title: When is potential energy equal to kinetic energy in a simple harmonic motion during a period? - Quora

response.answer_text: Since we’re talking about energy it’s nicer to refer to the displacement instead of the time (when). So use the formula F(x)=-kx, and integrate it with respect to distance, which gives you the energy as a function of distance. Say you displace it one unit, then release it. The potential energy is equal to kinetic energy (because energy is conserved), when it is displaced [math]\frac{1}{\sqrt(2)}[/math] from the equilibrium point, which is about 0.71 units. If you want to know when, I’d say “When you do your own homework.”
Max PE and max KE? Or PE=KE? Generally speaking, when the KE is cut in half. (Presumably the other half is PE).
